summary.p: [1] If Bullinger considers the booklet on the English Reformation [“Mandatorum epitome”] sent to him by Vadian [with No. 3058] to be truthful, he should also send it to Ambrosius Blarer at Vadian's behest. He would very much like to read it and will ensure its return.
[2] As the messenger [...] is departing, Vadian writes only briefly and in haste.
[3] Greetings. Bullinger should write again when he has time.

div.p: Greetings. If you consider the booklet on the English Reformation sent to you to be trustworthy, I kindly ask you to send it to Ambrosius Blarer on my behalf. He is eager to have and read it. He will ensure that it is returned to me eventually.
I did not have time to write more due to the departing messenger. I wrote this almost standing on one foot.
Farewell, therefore, by the grace of Christ, and when you have time, do not hesitate to write to me. St. Gallen, the third day before the Nones of November, in the year 1547.
To Lord Heinrich Bullinger, president of the illustrious city of Zurich, his most esteemed lord and friend.
